THE NEWS LETT KR
VOL. XV, NO. 3.
HOBOKENITES HUMBLE HOPKINS
BlaclCand Blue Gridiron Gladiators Play
Poorly and Lose Fumbles
Were Frequent.

In a poor exhibition of football
the Hopkins football team went
clown to defeat at the hands of the
Stevens' eleven, 2 to o, Saturday
afternoon at Homewood. Stevens
seemed to be able to go through
the Hopkins line at will, and repeatedly carried the ball to within
several yards of the Hopkins goal
line. The one bright spot in the
Hopkins play was the way the
Black and Blue held its opponents
under the shadow of its own goal
posts. Three times Stevens advanced the pigskin within less than
ten yards of the Hopkins goal line,
only to be held for downs. Buttfield, the Stevens quarter, showed
poor judgment in always trying to
make the required distance on the
third down, and not trying a dropkick when directly in front of the
goal posts. In the last quarter, a
dropkick would have been worth
as much to the visitors as a touchdown.
Forward passes were worked successfully by SteArens, directly over
the line of scrimmage. Many of
them should have been blocked by
Hopkins. Both sides made so many
fumbles that the spectators' were
prepared for almost anything. The
Hopkins line will have to be
strengthened. The guard positions
especially seemed to be weak spots.
Penniman's absence is severely felt
by Hopkins. Read, the big giant
from the Medical School, played
Saturday without having had a
practice. His work under the circumstances was good, and be will
greatly strengthen the team in the
rest of the games this season.
The Hopkins players tackled poorly. Their object appeared to be to
grab their opponents by the ears, if
Possible, instead of tackling low, as
they should have done. Poor tackling on the part of the Black and
Blue several times enabled the
Stevens back to advance 8 or 10
yards after being tackled,
Pieper caught the ball on the
kick-off and advanced it to Hopkins
3o-yard line. On the second
play Gillet carried the pigskin well
into the midfield on a forward pass.
Stevens held Hopkins for downs
and secured the spheroid. It changed
hands several times before the
end of the quarter. Harris tried a
drop kick, but failed. The quarter
ended with Hopkins in possession
of the ball on its 14-yard line. In
the second quarter Howe caught
Captain Stollenwerck's punt and
ran 60 yards through the whole

BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 17, 1910.
-••

Hopkins team for a touchdown.
This was'not allowed by the referee
as a Stevens player committed afoul.
In this session of play, Stevens
carried the ball to Hopkins' 4-yard
line, but lost it on downs.
The third quarter was hard
fought and ended with Stevens in
possession of the ball on Hopkins'
27-yard line. Twice in the last
period of play Stevens advanced
the pigskin within striking distance
of the goal line, but were held by
the Black and Blue. Gillet booted
the ball out of danger the first time,
but on his second attempt the line
held poorly. This enabled White
to break through and block the punt.
White dropped the ball and Gillet recovered it behind the goal line,
scoring a safety. This lost the
game for the Black and Blue.
Ackermann at right halfback played a star game for the winners.
His nose was broken, but he
pluckily finished out the game.

Freshmen Win Class Rush.

During the intermission between
the halves of the football game the
annual class rush was held. The
sophomores and freshmen lined up
on the gridiron about.twenty yards
apart, and at the sound of the
whistle blown by Chief Judge
Harold B. Hering they rushed for
each other.
The rush consisted of three
rounds of one minute each. At
the end of that time the class having
the least number of members on
the ground was adjudged the winner. Contrary to expectations,
the judges allowed the members of
each class who showed up to take
part. It had been understood that
the sides were to be equal. The
freshmen had about forty-five combatants and the sophomores thirty.
In spite of the overwhelming
odds, the sophs put up a gallant
fight, and actually succeeded in
winning one out of the three
rounds. The freshmen deserve
great credit for getting such a
large majority of the members of
their class to take part in the rush.

"THE SCHOLAR IN POLITICS"

Biologists Had Interesting and Profitable
Summer at Marine Laboratory and
in Mountains of Jamaica.

Woodrow Wilson, Graduate of This University, Making Strong Fight for
Gubernatorial Chair.

The history of the relations of
the Johns Hopkins University with
the island of Jamaica is long and
interesting. It is now nearly
twenty years since the late Professor Brooks established the first laboratory on the southern shore of
the island, a few miles from Kingston. Work was carried on in this
laboratory for many years, but Professor Brooks was not entirely satisfied with the location, because of
trade winds which blow almost incessantly and make work on marine
animals difficult. It was then that
Professor Andrews circled the island (it is 150 miles long and 50
miles wide), largely on foot, to find
a better site for a marine laboratory. He found that Montego Bay,
on the northwestern coast, was excellently adapted to work on marine
animals. The coast line is fringed
by mountains 1500 to 2000 feet in
height, which rise to an altitude of
a mile in the interior of the island.
The bay is therefore well protected
from the trade winds and it is possible to venture far out in an open
boat without danger of being
swamped. At this time, however,
Montego Bay was very difficult of
access. There were no boat lines
running there, and there was no
railroad from Kingston. So the
change of location could not be
made at the time.
This year, however, an expedition was organized under auspicious circumstances. It was the first
expedition since the disastrous one
to Port Antonio (on the northeast
coast) in 19o1, when Professors
Humphrey and Conant lost their
lives through yellow fever. In the
period since Professor Andrews'
first visit to Montego Bay, regular
boat service has been established
between this town and Baltimore,
Philadelphia and New York, and
the railroad to Kingston has been
completed, making communication
with the rest of the island a simple
matter.
The expedition went in two sections; the botanists leaving May II,
whereas the zoologists did not go
until June. The memEers of the
party were: Professor Andrews,
Dr. Graves, Dr. Cowles, Messrs.
Wilson, Givler, Middleton, and
Lund; Prof. Johnson and Messrs.
York. Brown, and Sharp. The
botanists, under Prof. Johnson,
spent the greater part of the time
high up in the mountains, while the
zoologists, with Prof. Andrews,

Hopkins is too young to have
many famous graduates, and the
theory in education which the University has stood for has been of
such a character that the men who
chose to come here and study have
not, as a rule, entered those vocations in which it is easiest to
achieve fame. If the roster of those
Hopkins alumni who hold important professorial and scientific positions were gone over, it would be
found that we stand second to none.
But the men whom the public gets
to know easiest are the politicians,
the statesmen, and the candidates
for office. But among these public
figures, many of whom are being
mentioned as presidential possibilities, is a Democratic candidate for
governor,- a Hopkins man who is
making a good fight, with fine
chances for success, and is rallying
to his support as a political leader,
a vast following.
Starting out in life as a lawyer,
and then deciding that his vocation
lay in educational lines, and preparing himself for this work by coming
to Hopkins, Woodrow Wilson, now
candidate for governor on the Democratic ticket in New Jersey, is the
most illustrious example today of
the muth-discussed scholar in politics, and is without doubt Hopkins'
most famous alumnus. With his elevation to the presidency of Princeton University he came near being the most famous educator, as
well as one of the greatest scholars
which the University had produced; but in his new role which
he essays without solicitation on
his part, and only on the united
request of the Democrats of New
Jersey, he is one of the great public
figures of the day, with presidential
possibilities which, when the next
convention is held, will have to be
looked out for.
The information possessed by the
ordinary voter relative to candidates for office is, we may say, of
two kinds. With a man who has
had an interesting and almost fantastic life, as had Lincoln, the
people know more of his personal
history than they do of what he
stands for, or his mental attainments and capacity concerning political problems. But with Wilson,
the case is different. The country
knows that he is an author of note,
that he is an authority on questions
dealing with the problems which
confront the legislative, judicial and
executive departments of the gov-

MANY SPECIMENS SECURED
(Continued from page 1.)

stayed at the marine laboratory on

the bay.

Montego Bay is well adapted to
a study of marine life. First of all,
the coast is fringed by coral reefs
which furnish an abundance of interesting material. Secondly, being
the lee shore of the island, a great
deal of material collects on the surface of the water close to shore,
drifting in from the surrounding
ocean and carried in by the tide.
Thirdly, there is a group of islands
very irregular in shape and of small
extent just off the shore, which
were probably formed by the settling of the land. These islands
are covered with a dense growth of
mangrove trees, which hang their
roots in the water. All manner
of animals collect .on these roots;
and it is only necessary to row to
a tree and lift one of the roots
into the boat in order to get tubs
full of all kinds and descriptions.
A great mass of material was
brought back for study. Among
the many interesting objects was
a live lizard a foot and a half or
two feet long,'which weighed ten
pounds. Unfortunately, it died last
week. When .Columbus came to
America, there were a great many
,of these lizards in Jamaica, but now
they have almost entirely disappeared. The disappearance of this
species of lizard is due principally
to the mongoose. The mongoose
was originally imported from India
for the purpose .of destroying the
nts, which are a great pest on the
island. But the rats were at work
while the mongoose slept; and,
moreover, a mongoose cannot climb
a tree, .which is a simple problem
for the Jamaican rat. The result
was that the mongoose turned elsewhere for a living, and is doing
more damage than the rats formerly did.
A large number of hermit, crabs
were brought back and are now
kept alive in the biological laboratory. These crabs live in the shells
of snails, and carry the shell around
with them when they move about.
Professor Andrews studied snails
and termites particularly.
He.
brought back with him.several hundred snail shells for further study.
Although it was supposed that the
fauna of Jamaica had been thor°uglily studied and classified,nevertheless Mr. Wilson, of Chicago,
found no less than fifty new species
of marine animals, most of them

parasitic on fish. Dr. Cowles
studied sea urchin's and starfish,
particularly their manner of moving about. Mr. Middleton studied
the habits of termites, or white ants.
Mr. Lund was busied with phosphorescent animals, which occur
here in unusually large numbers
and varieties. And Mr. Givler was
interested in the life history of certain crabs.
Of the material brought back,
some is intended for the museum,
some for reSearch work., and some
for dissection in Biology; 3. On the
whole, the expedition was an unqualified success, and well worth
the time, labor and money expended
upon it.
Early Lacrosse Practice.

Lacrosse practice has now started
—not regular practice, but just a
little recreation after working hours.
Every day at five can be seen eight
or ten men with their lacrosse
clothes on, which are not much, running around- the cage. There is
now a good chance for new men
to get out and practice handling a
stick, so when the regular practice
starts, the coaches won't have to
use their lungs So much. Captain
Hulbert is in the cage every day at
five o'clock, and will show all new
men how to handle a stick, and
various other points for beginners.
When regular practice starts, the
fellows who know how to use their
sticks will have an advantage. Lacrosse is a ga:ne of consistent practice and cannot be learned in a day,
but takes years. Those who have
not got sticks should see Manager
Makel and get one.
Alumni Notes.

Earnest A. Smith, Ph. D., 1900,
who was for a number of years
professor of history and political
economy at Allegheny College, has
been appointed preceptor and assistant professor in political economy at Princeton University.
Guy E. Snavely, Ph. D., 1903,
has been promoted to the position
of professor of Romance languages
at Allegheny College. He was
formerly a professor of French.
David S. Blondheim, A.B., '06,
Ph.D., '10, is professor of French
at the University of Illinois. His
dissertation, which was written in
French, is to be published in Romania, a French publication which
holds a high position abroad.
John • N. Ware, Ph.D., '10, is a
member of the French Department

Prominent Graduate Dead.

Chemists Need Room.

A loss of great sadness to many
members of the University, and of
the alumni, occurred on September
18, when Professor John E.
Matzke, a doctor of philosophy of
this institution, died in the City .of
Mexico.
Dr. Matzke was born in the city
of Breslau, Germany, in the year
1862. Coming to this country, he
received his collegiate education at
Hope College, and from that institution came to the Romance department of the Hopkins. He received
his degree in 1888, and immediately
took a position in the faculty of
*Bowdoin College. Later, he went
to the University of Indiana, and
in 1893 took charge of the Romance
department at Leland Stanford, Jr.,
University, a position which he held
until his death.
FIe was widely known among
language scholars, and will be long
remembered for a long and masterful series of works upon old and
modern French literature and
grammar, besides numerous French
and Spanish texts which he edited.
One of his most valuable contributions to modern language study is
his Spanish grammar, which in a
sense, revolutionized the teaching
of that language, by first applying
to it modern methods.

Record breaking is the number of
students in the chemical department of the University according
to Prof. Harry C. Jones, professor of physical chemistry. Both
undergraduates and graduate students are taking chemistry in numbers previously unknown in the
department. More than 150 separate students are enrolled in the
different classes or doing special
work in the laboratories. There
are more than 40 graduates who
are making chemistry their major,
and of these more than 30 are
regularly entered as candidates for
the degree of doctor of philosophy
in this department.
That such a number of students
overtaxes the provisions of the
laboratories goes without saying
when the conditions that usually
prevail there are known. While
the work is in no sense hampered,
still the want of greater room and
more facilities is being forced upon
the attention of the instructors by
the crowded condition. Professor
Jones was quite emphatic on this
point, and declared the need for
expansion was becoming imperative.
"The growth of our department," he concluded, "can be attributed to nothing but our work.
Our effort is to make our results
speak for themselves."

Dr. Burgan in Charge.

One of the most important departments of the University is the
new Training School for future
managers, recently opened with Dr.
Harry C. Burgan at its head. This
department is expected to be of the
greatest service to the student
body, as capable managers were
becoming scarce. The selection of
Dr. Burgan as head of the department will go a long ways towards
making it successful. He is fully
conversant with all the intricacies
pertaining to a managership, having spent the better part of his lifetime in managerial research work.
An unusually large enrollment is
expected in this department, as Dr.
Burgan agrees to secure positions
for all his graduates. The class is
studying at present a comprehensive volume on -The Gentle Art
of Issuing Passes," by Dr. Harry
C. Burgan, but" during the second
term the students will take up advanced work with laboratory every
afternoon.

17, 1910

The class in Geology I took the
first trip of the year last Wednesday. The weather was fine for
walking, and the entire class, some
twenty men, went. The excursion
was a short one. Lansdowne was
reached by train, and from there the
party set out to study the geology
of the region between Lansdowne
and Halethorpe. Among many
other interesting objects, there was
a minature canon, which was perfectly analogous in almost every
particular to the canons of the
Rocky Mountains. Dr. Swartz expects to take the class on twenty or
more excursions during the year.

New Society Organizes.

The first meeting of the new Arbitration Society was held in Levering Hall on Friday of last week,
and was attended by a number of
those interested in the subject.
L. B. Bobbitt presided and read a
tentative constitution for the body,
which was adopted with some
amendments. The following officers
were elected:
President—L. B. Bobbitt,
Vice-President—Lindsay Rogers,
'12.
'Secretary—T. B. Price, '12.
Treasurer — Bertram Benedict,
'12.
Librarian—J. S. Dickinson, '13.
It is expected that several prominent local figures in the peace movement will lend their names to the
society as honorary vice-presidents.
Senior Class Election.

At a meeting of the Senior Class,
held Friday, October 14, the following officers were elected: President, Harold Brooks Herring; vicepresident, Benjamin Tappan; secretary, Harry Linden; treasurer,
John B. Reeside ; sergeant-at-arms,
J. Reaney Wolfe. After a resolution in regard to the payment of
back class dues, the meeting adjourned.

THE NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 17, 1910
Elevator Has Dropsy.

In last week's issue of THE
NEWS-LETTER an article was published to the effect that a new elevator had been installed and that
there would be no futher inconvenience in having it stop between
floors.
Since then a week has
passed. During that time, the actions of the aforesaid elevator have
been very unusual. To speak in
figurative language one might say
that it has a very distressing disease
—the dropsy. It has acquired the
habit of dropping from about the •
first floor to the bottom of the shaft
with astonishing rapidity, and causing a jar to the passengers within
that is not conducive to the most
agreeable sensations.
Since this
developed, the stairways have been
thronged with students not willing
to risk themselves to the treachery
of such an uncontrollable machine.
This exercise may be rather advantageous to those in training
for athletic teams, but to the others
it seems rather laborious.
Speaking in a more serious attitude, however, it is to be hoped
that the elevator will be • fixed _so
that there may be no danger of its
falling, for the results might have
been disastrous had it fallen from
the third or fourth floor, instead of
the first.
Autos Must Have Tickets.

A lengthy meeting of the Athletic
Board was held on last Monday, at
which Gus Sattler, of the sophomore class, was elected manager of
the baseball team, and Lynn Meekins was chosen to assist him. Ernest
J. Pieper will be captain of the
team.
The Board also fixed the scale
of prices that is to prevail at the
football games this year. Prices
will be increased for those not having season tickets at the game with
the Carlisle Indians, and possibly
at other games that will be specially
advertised. A new charge of fifty
cents was decided upon for admission of automobiles, in addition to
the admission tickets for the occupants of the machines; at the games
where the higher scale of prices is
to prevail, this will be
made a
dollar.

(THE NEWS-LETTER is always glad to
publish letters of reasonable length
upon topics of interest in the University
circles. Alumni especially are urged
to make use of this column.)

Editor of THE NEws-LETTER.
There has been a decided wave
of enthusiasm throughaut the freshman class in favor of Johns Hopkins University having a basketball
team this year; now is the time to
have the schedule made and the
team organized.
Every American college of prominence has taken up basketball, and
consider it now one of the most
important games; such universities
as Yale, Harvard, Princeton, Cornell, Pennsylvania having fast
teams well known all over the
country, a drawing card wherever
they play. Even Navy and West
Point, generally slow in taking up
sports, took up basketball three
years ago, and the athletic associations recognized the teams. Even
University of Maryland had a team
last year, advertising their college
with a Nothern trip, on which they
played Cornell, Syracuse, Pennsylvania State, etc. St. John's, our
dearest rival, put out a team last
year and wished to play Johns Hopkins University, but we had no
team.
Shall our University be the last
to take up the sport? Shall Johns
Hopkins University be looked down
on by other American colleges?
Shall our athletics go backward
while those of other colleges are
advancing? Or shall we step to the
forefront with a basketball team,
and play University of Virginia,
Georgetown, Navy, Princeton, who
take a Southern trip annually, and
other big colleges, winding up with
our victory over old St. John's?
Of course there will be objections
right away to basketball. There
are always thpse who kick at every
improvement; if we listen to them
we will never advance.
What objections are there? If
any, cannot they be offset by the
following: We have one of the
best gymnasiums in the city for
basketball. The whole expense of
a team would not be over $50. We
have the best of material, fellows
who have played on the best teams
in this city. We could get a coach
for next to nothing. We could
draw big crowds and make money
for the athletic associations. We
could play the big colleges if the
schedule is made now. In short,
the advantages would be enormous,
and the disadvantages not worth
speaking of.
Hopkins is the laughing stock of
American colleges in athletics. Let
us make them laugh another tune
by getting out a basketball team
and winning fame. Basketball is
the coming game. A stitch in time
saves nine.
AN ARDENT rRESHMAN.

BlaclCand Blue Gridiron Gladiators Play
Poorly and Lose Fumbles
Were Frequent.

In a poor exhibition of football
the Hopkins football team went
clown to defeat at the hands of the
Stevens' eleven, 2 to o, Saturday
afternoon at Homewood. Stevens
seemed to be able to go through
the Hopkins line at will, and repeatedly carried the ball to within
several yards of the Hopkins goal
line. The one bright spot in the
Hopkins play was the way the
Black and Blue held its opponents
under the shadow of its own goal
posts. Three times Stevens advanced the pigskin within less than
ten yards of the Hopkins goal line,
only to be held for downs. Buttfield, the Stevens quarter, showed
poor judgment in always trying to
make the required distance on the
third down, and not trying a dropkick when directly in front of the
goal posts. In the last quarter, a
dropkick would have been worth
as much to the visitors as a touchdown.
Forward passes were worked successfully by SteArens, directly over
the line of scrimmage. Many of
them should have been blocked by
Hopkins. Both sides made so many
fumbles that the spectators' were
prepared for almost anything. The
Hopkins line will have to be
strengthened. The guard positions
especially seemed to be weak spots.
Penniman's absence is severely felt
by Hopkins. Read, the big giant
from the Medical School, played
Saturday without having had a
practice. His work under the circumstances was good, and be will
greatly strengthen the team in the
rest of the games this season.
The Hopkins players tackled poorly. Their object appeared to be to
grab their opponents by the ears, if
Possible, instead of tackling low, as
they should have done. Poor tackling on the part of the Black and
Blue several times enabled the
Stevens back to advance 8 or 10
yards after being tackled,
Pieper caught the ball on the
kick-off and advanced it to Hopkins
3o-yard line. On the second
play Gillet carried the pigskin well
into the midfield on a forward pass.
Stevens held Hopkins for downs
and secured the spheroid. It changed
hands several times before the
end of the quarter. Harris tried a
drop kick, but failed. The quarter
ended with Hopkins in possession
of the ball on its 14-yard line. In
the second quarter Howe caught
Captain Stollenwerck's punt and
ran 60 yards through the whole

Freshmen Win Class Rush.

During the intermission between
the halves of the football game the
annual class rush was held. The
sophomores and freshmen lined up
on the gridiron about.twenty yards
apart, and at the sound of the
whistle blown by Chief Judge
Harold B. Hering they rushed for
each other.
The rush consisted of three
rounds of one minute each. At
the end of that time the class having
the least number of members on
the ground was adjudged the winner. Contrary to expectations,
the judges allowed the members of
each class who showed up to take
part. It had been understood that
the sides were to be equal. The
freshmen had about forty-five combatants and the sophomores thirty.
In spite of the overwhelming
odds, the sophs put up a gallant
fight, and actually succeeded in
winning one out of the three
rounds. The freshmen deserve
great credit for getting such a
large majority of the members of
their class to take part in the rush.

"THE SCHOLAR IN POLITICS"

Biologists Had Interesting and Profitable
Summer at Marine Laboratory and
in Mountains of Jamaica.

Woodrow Wilson, Graduate of This University, Making Strong Fight for
Gubernatorial Chair.

The history of the relations of
the Johns Hopkins University with
the island of Jamaica is long and
interesting. It is now nearly
twenty years since the late Professor Brooks established the first laboratory on the southern shore of
the island, a few miles from Kingston. Work was carried on in this
laboratory for many years, but Professor Brooks was not entirely satisfied with the location, because of
trade winds which blow almost incessantly and make work on marine
animals difficult. It was then that
Professor Andrews circled the island (it is 150 miles long and 50
miles wide), largely on foot, to find
a better site for a marine laboratory. He found that Montego Bay,
on the northwestern coast, was excellently adapted to work on marine
animals. The coast line is fringed
by mountains 1500 to 2000 feet in
height, which rise to an altitude of
a mile in the interior of the island.
The bay is therefore well protected
from the trade winds and it is possible to venture far out in an open
boat without danger of being
swamped. At this time, however,
Montego Bay was very difficult of
access. There were no boat lines
running there, and there was no
railroad from Kingston. So the
change of location could not be
made at the time.
This year, however, an expedition was organized under auspicious circumstances. It was the first
expedition since the disastrous one
to Port Antonio (on the northeast
coast) in 19o1, when Professors
Humphrey and Conant lost their
lives through yellow fever. In the
period since Professor Andrews'
first visit to Montego Bay, regular
boat service has been established
between this town and Baltimore,
Philadelphia and New York, and
the railroad to Kingston has been
completed, making communication
with the rest of the island a simple
matter.
The expedition went in two sections; the botanists leaving May II,
whereas the zoologists did not go
until June. The memEers of the
party were: Professor Andrews,
Dr. Graves, Dr. Cowles, Messrs.
Wilson, Givler, Middleton, and
Lund; Prof. Johnson and Messrs.
York. Brown, and Sharp. The
botanists, under Prof. Johnson,
spent the greater part of the time
high up in the mountains, while the
zoologists, with Prof. Andrews,

Hopkins is too young to have
many famous graduates, and the
theory in education which the University has stood for has been of
such a character that the men who
chose to come here and study have
not, as a rule, entered those vocations in which it is easiest to
achieve fame. If the roster of those
Hopkins alumni who hold important professorial and scientific positions were gone over, it would be
found that we stand second to none.
But the men whom the public gets
to know easiest are the politicians,
the statesmen, and the candidates
for office. But among these public
figures, many of whom are being
mentioned as presidential possibilities, is a Democratic candidate for
governor,- a Hopkins man who is
making a good fight, with fine
chances for success, and is rallying
to his support as a political leader,
a vast following.
Starting out in life as a lawyer,
and then deciding that his vocation
lay in educational lines, and preparing himself for this work by coming
to Hopkins, Woodrow Wilson, now
candidate for governor on the Democratic ticket in New Jersey, is the
most illustrious example today of
the muth-discussed scholar in politics, and is without doubt Hopkins'
most famous alumnus. With his elevation to the presidency of Princeton University he came near being the most famous educator, as
well as one of the greatest scholars
which the University had produced; but in his new role which
he essays without solicitation on
his part, and only on the united
request of the Democrats of New
Jersey, he is one of the great public
figures of the day, with presidential
possibilities which, when the next
convention is held, will have to be
looked out for.
The information possessed by the
ordinary voter relative to candidates for office is, we may say, of
two kinds. With a man who has
had an interesting and almost fantastic life, as had Lincoln, the
people know more of his personal
history than they do of what he
stands for, or his mental attainments and capacity concerning political problems. But with Wilson,
the case is different. The country
knows that he is an author of note,
that he is an authority on questions
dealing with the problems which
confront the legislative, judicial and
executive departments of the gov-

MANY SPECIMENS SECURED
(Continued from page 1.)

stayed at the marine laboratory on

the bay.

Montego Bay is well adapted to
a study of marine life. First of all,
the coast is fringed by coral reefs
which furnish an abundance of interesting material. Secondly, being
the lee shore of the island, a great
deal of material collects on the surface of the water close to shore,
drifting in from the surrounding
ocean and carried in by the tide.
Thirdly, there is a group of islands
very irregular in shape and of small
extent just off the shore, which
were probably formed by the settling of the land. These islands
are covered with a dense growth of
mangrove trees, which hang their
roots in the water. All manner
of animals collect .on these roots;
and it is only necessary to row to
a tree and lift one of the roots
into the boat in order to get tubs
full of all kinds and descriptions.
A great mass of material was
brought back for study. Among
the many interesting objects was
a live lizard a foot and a half or
two feet long,'which weighed ten
pounds. Unfortunately, it died last
week. When .Columbus came to
America, there were a great many
,of these lizards in Jamaica, but now
they have almost entirely disappeared. The disappearance of this
species of lizard is due principally
to the mongoose. The mongoose
was originally imported from India
for the purpose .of destroying the
nts, which are a great pest on the
island. But the rats were at work
while the mongoose slept; and,
moreover, a mongoose cannot climb
a tree, .which is a simple problem
for the Jamaican rat. The result
was that the mongoose turned elsewhere for a living, and is doing
more damage than the rats formerly did.
A large number of hermit, crabs
were brought back and are now
kept alive in the biological laboratory. These crabs live in the shells
of snails, and carry the shell around
with them when they move about.
Professor Andrews studied snails
and termites particularly.
He.
brought back with him.several hundred snail shells for further study.
Although it was supposed that the
fauna of Jamaica had been thor°uglily studied and classified,nevertheless Mr. Wilson, of Chicago,
found no less than fifty new species
of marine animals, most of them

parasitic on fish. Dr. Cowles
studied sea urchin's and starfish,
particularly their manner of moving about. Mr. Middleton studied
the habits of termites, or white ants.
Mr. Lund was busied with phosphorescent animals, which occur
here in unusually large numbers
and varieties. And Mr. Givler was
interested in the life history of certain crabs.
Of the material brought back,
some is intended for the museum,
some for reSearch work., and some
for dissection in Biology; 3. On the
whole, the expedition was an unqualified success, and well worth
the time, labor and money expended
upon it.
Early Lacrosse Practice.

Lacrosse practice has now started
—not regular practice, but just a
little recreation after working hours.
Every day at five can be seen eight
or ten men with their lacrosse
clothes on, which are not much, running around- the cage. There is
now a good chance for new men
to get out and practice handling a
stick, so when the regular practice
starts, the coaches won't have to
use their lungs So much. Captain
Hulbert is in the cage every day at
five o'clock, and will show all new
men how to handle a stick, and
various other points for beginners.
When regular practice starts, the
fellows who know how to use their
sticks will have an advantage. Lacrosse is a ga:ne of consistent practice and cannot be learned in a day,
but takes years. Those who have
not got sticks should see Manager
Makel and get one.

who was for a number of years
professor of history and political
economy at Allegheny College, has
been appointed preceptor and assistant professor in political economy at Princeton University.
Guy E. Snavely, Ph. D., 1903,
has been promoted to the position
of professor of Romance languages
at Allegheny College. He was
formerly a professor of French.
David S. Blondheim, A.B., '06,
Ph.D., '10, is professor of French
at the University of Illinois. His
dissertation, which was written in
French, is to be published in Romania, a French publication which
holds a high position abroad.

Prominent Graduate Dead.

Chemists Need Room.

A loss of great sadness to many
members of the University, and of
the alumni, occurred on September
18, when Professor John E.
Matzke, a doctor of philosophy of
this institution, died in the City .of
Mexico.
Dr. Matzke was born in the city
of Breslau, Germany, in the year
1862. Coming to this country, he
received his collegiate education at
Hope College, and from that institution came to the Romance department of the Hopkins. He received
his degree in 1888, and immediately
took a position in the faculty of
*Bowdoin College. Later, he went
to the University of Indiana, and
in 1893 took charge of the Romance
department at Leland Stanford, Jr.,
University, a position which he held
until his death.
FIe was widely known among
language scholars, and will be long
remembered for a long and masterful series of works upon old and
modern French literature and
grammar, besides numerous French
and Spanish texts which he edited.
One of his most valuable contributions to modern language study is
his Spanish grammar, which in a
sense, revolutionized the teaching
of that language, by first applying
to it modern methods.

Record breaking is the number of
students in the chemical department of the University according
to Prof. Harry C. Jones, professor of physical chemistry. Both
undergraduates and graduate students are taking chemistry in numbers previously unknown in the
department. More than 150 separate students are enrolled in the
different classes or doing special
work in the laboratories. There
are more than 40 graduates who
are making chemistry their major,
and of these more than 30 are
regularly entered as candidates for
the degree of doctor of philosophy
in this department.
That such a number of students
overtaxes the provisions of the
laboratories goes without saying
when the conditions that usually
prevail there are known. While
the work is in no sense hampered,
still the want of greater room and
more facilities is being forced upon
the attention of the instructors by
the crowded condition. Professor
Jones was quite emphatic on this
point, and declared the need for
expansion was becoming imperative.
"The growth of our department," he concluded, "can be attributed to nothing but our work.
Our effort is to make our results
speak for themselves."

Dr. Burgan in Charge.

One of the most important departments of the University is the
new Training School for future
managers, recently opened with Dr.
Harry C. Burgan at its head. This
department is expected to be of the
greatest service to the student
body, as capable managers were
becoming scarce. The selection of
Dr. Burgan as head of the department will go a long ways towards
making it successful. He is fully
conversant with all the intricacies
pertaining to a managership, having spent the better part of his lifetime in managerial research work.
An unusually large enrollment is
expected in this department, as Dr.
Burgan agrees to secure positions
for all his graduates. The class is
studying at present a comprehensive volume on -The Gentle Art
of Issuing Passes," by Dr. Harry
C. Burgan, but" during the second
term the students will take up advanced work with laboratory every
afternoon.

17, 1910

The class in Geology I took the
first trip of the year last Wednesday. The weather was fine for
walking, and the entire class, some
twenty men, went. The excursion
was a short one. Lansdowne was
reached by train, and from there the
party set out to study the geology
of the region between Lansdowne
and Halethorpe. Among many
other interesting objects, there was
a minature canon, which was perfectly analogous in almost every
particular to the canons of the
Rocky Mountains. Dr. Swartz expects to take the class on twenty or
more excursions during the year.

New Society Organizes.

The first meeting of the new Arbitration Society was held in Levering Hall on Friday of last week,
and was attended by a number of
those interested in the subject.
L. B. Bobbitt presided and read a
tentative constitution for the body,
which was adopted with some
amendments. The following officers
were elected:
President—L. B. Bobbitt,
Vice-President—Lindsay Rogers,
'12.
'Secretary—T. B. Price, '12.
Treasurer — Bertram Benedict,
'12.
Librarian—J. S. Dickinson, '13.
It is expected that several prominent local figures in the peace movement will lend their names to the
society as honorary vice-presidents.
Senior Class Election.

At a meeting of the Senior Class,
held Friday, October 14, the following officers were elected: President, Harold Brooks Herring; vicepresident, Benjamin Tappan; secretary, Harry Linden; treasurer,
John B. Reeside ; sergeant-at-arms,
J. Reaney Wolfe. After a resolution in regard to the payment of
back class dues, the meeting adjourned.

THE NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 17, 1910
Elevator Has Dropsy.

In last week's issue of THE
NEWS-LETTER an article was published to the effect that a new elevator had been installed and that
there would be no futher inconvenience in having it stop between
floors.
Since then a week has
passed. During that time, the actions of the aforesaid elevator have
been very unusual. To speak in
figurative language one might say
that it has a very distressing disease
—the dropsy. It has acquired the
habit of dropping from about the •
first floor to the bottom of the shaft
with astonishing rapidity, and causing a jar to the passengers within
that is not conducive to the most
agreeable sensations.
Since this
developed, the stairways have been
thronged with students not willing
to risk themselves to the treachery
of such an uncontrollable machine.
This exercise may be rather advantageous to those in training
for athletic teams, but to the others
it seems rather laborious.
Speaking in a more serious attitude, however, it is to be hoped
that the elevator will be • fixed _so
that there may be no danger of its
falling, for the results might have
been disastrous had it fallen from
the third or fourth floor, instead of
the first.
Autos Must Have Tickets.

A lengthy meeting of the Athletic
Board was held on last Monday, at
which Gus Sattler, of the sophomore class, was elected manager of
the baseball team, and Lynn Meekins was chosen to assist him. Ernest
J. Pieper will be captain of the
team.
The Board also fixed the scale
of prices that is to prevail at the
football games this year. Prices
will be increased for those not having season tickets at the game with
the Carlisle Indians, and possibly
at other games that will be specially
advertised. A new charge of fifty
cents was decided upon for admission of automobiles, in addition to
the admission tickets for the occupants of the machines; at the games
where the higher scale of prices is
to prevail, this will be
made a
dollar.
Senior Class Meeting.

COMMUNICATIONS
(THE NEWS-LETTER is always glad to
publish letters of reasonable length
upon topics of interest in the University
circles. Alumni especially are urged
to make use of this column.)

Editor of THE NEws-LETTER.
There has been a decided wave
of enthusiasm throughaut the freshman class in favor of Johns Hopkins University having a basketball
team this year; now is the time to
have the schedule made and the
team organized.
Every American college of prominence has taken up basketball, and
consider it now one of the most
important games; such universities
as Yale, Harvard, Princeton, Cornell, Pennsylvania having fast
teams well known all over the
country, a drawing card wherever
they play. Even Navy and West
Point, generally slow in taking up
sports, took up basketball three
years ago, and the athletic associations recognized the teams. Even
University of Maryland had a team
last year, advertising their college
with a Nothern trip, on which they
played Cornell, Syracuse, Pennsylvania State, etc. St. John's, our
dearest rival, put out a team last
year and wished to play Johns Hopkins University, but we had no
team.
Shall our University be the last
to take up the sport? Shall Johns
Hopkins University be looked down
on by other American colleges?
Shall our athletics go backward
while those of other colleges are
advancing? Or shall we step to the
forefront with a basketball team,
and play University of Virginia,
Georgetown, Navy, Princeton, who
take a Southern trip annually, and
other big colleges, winding up with
our victory over old St. John's?
Of course there will be objections
right away to basketball. There
are always thpse who kick at every
improvement; if we listen to them
we will never advance.
What objections are there? If
any, cannot they be offset by the
following: We have one of the
best gymnasiums in the city for
basketball. The whole expense of
a team would not be over $50. We
have the best of material, fellows
who have played on the best teams
in this city. We could get a coach
for next to nothing. We could
draw big crowds and make money
for the athletic associations. We
could play the big colleges if the
schedule is made now. In short,
the advantages would be enormous,
and the disadvantages not worth
speaking of.
Hopkins is the laughing stock of
American colleges in athletics. Let
us make them laugh another tune
by getting out a basketball team
and winning fame. Basketball is
the coming game. A stitch in time
saves nine.
AN ARDENT rRESHMAN.
